comments.html:
Re: once I’ll share with you how I’ve learned that lesson the hard way
Please do. Not enough war stories, show us your scars ;)

Re: Can you guess what the topic of one of my upcoming webinars is going to be?
More IPv6, like implementation for ISPs in terms of connecting end users?
comments.name: Alexandra Stanovska

comments.html:

comments.html:

comments.name: Ivan Pepelnjak

comments.html: #2: Yes thought about that too, but maybe got influenced by omnipresent IPv6. After reading the article more than just skimming and downloading podcast (ouch for the quality) my next quess is something like securing your cloud?
comments.name: Alexandra Stanovska

comments.html: Thanks for the link to unifiedcomputingblog.com... if I'm missing something on the 10GE side, I'm definitely open to adjusting my figures.   In fact, with a line rate over 10G, the FCoE case gets even stronger.    I did account for the encapsulation overhead though...
comments.name: Dave Alexander

comments.html:
IEEE 802.3-2008 section 4 (http://standards.ieee.org/getieee802/download/802.3-2008_section4.pdf):

* Data rate to MAC layer is 10 Gbps (10GBASE-X or 10GBASE-R) or 9.95328 Gbps (10GBASE-W, rarely used) ... section 46.1.3
* Encoding can be 8B/10B or 64B/66B plus numerous other things. Good overview can be found in the table in section 44.1.4.4
comments.name: Ivan Pepelnjak

comments.html: Interesting - I'll take a look... sounds like it may be time to consolidate my post and comments into a rewrite.  In any case, with 10Gbps to the MAC layer (after encoding), it makes 10GE FCoE even better.   :)
comments.name: Dave Alexander
